sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The genusSalmonella is composed of two species, Salmonella enterica and Salmonella bongori. S. enterica is, in turn, divided into six subspecies, each designated by a name and group number: S. enterica subspecies enterica (group I), S. enterica subsp. salamae (group II), S. enterica subsp. arizonae (group IIIa), S. enterica subsp. diarizonae (group IIIb), S. enterica subsp. houtenae (group IV), and S. enterica subsp. indica (group VI). Serotypes of clinical or epidemiologic importance within each subspecies may also be assigned a common name, such as S. enterica subsp. enterica serotype Typhi and S. enterica subsp. enterica serotype Enteritidis, which can be designated S. Typhi and S. Enteritidis. Of note, all S. Typhi strains belong to O antigen serogroup D, which can still be used to putatively identify this serotype (1, 2). DNA-DNA hybridization experiments demonstrate >80% association among all S. enterica serotypes, which exceeds the accepted threshold of 70% for definition of a species (3). S. bongori (group IV) shares only 45 to 50% relatedness with S. enterica and has been designated a separate species (2). Within the order Enterobacterales, the genus Salmonella shares the greatest sequence similarity with Citrobacter, Escherichia, and Shigella (45 to 50%), followed by Klebsiella and Enterobacter (30 to 40%), and is least related to Serratia and Proteus (7 to 28%) (3).

The chromosome ofS. enterica is 4.3 to 5.0 Mbp and carries 4,500 to 5,400 genes (4). The core genome present in all serotypes is 1.5 Mbp; however, >96% of serotypes contain a conserved core genome that is 3.2 Mbp in size, roughly equivalent to 70% of the total genome (5). This core genome differs by approximately 1% between S. enterica serotypes and by 10% compared to the core genome of Escherichia coli (4). The use of whole-genome analysis has enabled identification of genetic markers unique to each subspecies, ranging from 9 for S. enterica subsp. enterica to 207 for S. enterica subsp. arizonae (5). These studies support the earlier DNA-DNA hybridization- and enzyme electrophoresis-based taxonomic organization of S. enterica into six subspecies or groups. Similar whole-genome analysis was unable to establish genetic markers that uniquely identified all serotypes within a subspecies; however, sets of markers universally present or absent from many serotypes were identified. These findings demonstrate the high degree of genetic conservation within Salmonella subspecies but also the heterogeneity that is likely responsible for differences in pathogenicity and antimicrobial resistance characteristics of individual serotypes.

S. enterica subsp. enterica serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A to C are unique among Salmonella serotypes in both their limited host range and pathogenesis. Genetically, S. Typhi isolates are highly clonal regardless of geographic origin and do not cluster among the other S. enterica subsp. enterica serotypes (2, 4). S. Typhi has one of the largest sets of universal genetic markers common to S. enterica serotypes but also contains among the fewest genetic markers defining a subspecies (5). Both features are indicative of recent divergence within the serogroup followed by genomic decay as this serotype adapted to the human host (4). S. Typhi and S. Paratyphi C also express the Vi capsular antigen, which is unique among Salmonella serotypes. This antigen is antiphagocytic and anti-inflammatory and aids in intracellular survival, which contributes to the systemic disease caused by these serotypes (6). The presence of this antigen has commonly been used to serologically identify S. Typhi, but Vi expression may be variable based on in vitro growth conditions. Molecular detection of genes involved in regulation and expression of Vi (tviB and viaB) has been employed to definitively identify S. Typhi isolates lacking phenotypic Vi expression.

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GENUS
sect2.para: Salmonella organisms are motile, non-spore-forming, facultatively anaerobic Gram-negative bacilli approximately 1 μm in width and 2 to 5 μm in length. They can be cultured on most common laboratory media, including Mueller-Hinton agar with or without sheep blood, MacConkey agar (MAC), Trypticase soy agar and broth, and a variety of selective and differential media utilized for isolation of Salmonella from stool specimens (see “Isolation Procedures”). When cultured on 5% sheep blood agar at 35°C, colonies are large, moist, and gray to translucent and may be apparent following as little as 12 to 16 h of incubation. Motility in liquid culture is driven by expression of 2 to 4 flagella and can be observed microscopically as directed movement in wet-mount preparations. Salmonella spp. are capable of swarming motility in semisolid agar (0.5 to 0.8%) via cell elongation and expression of an increased number of flagella; however, swarming is not observed on solid agar (>1.5%) routinely used for bacterial culture in the laboratory (7). Salmonella spp. also express a number of pili and fimbriae in vivo that mediate attachment to and colonization of the gastric mucosa (8).

Salmonella spp. are oxidase negative and ferment glucose with production of gas, with the exception of S. enterica subsp. enterica serotype Typhi, which does not produce gas. Salmonella spp. are positive for lysine decarboxylase, with the exception of S. enterica subsp. enterica serotype Paratyphi; >98% of isolates are negative for lactose and sucrose fermentation, indole production, urease, and β-galactosidase (Table 1). Over 90% of clinically isolated Salmonella strains produce H2S, but production by S. enterica subsp. enterica serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A is scant and negative, respectively.

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Over 2,500 uniqueSalmonella O:H serotypes are currently recognized worldwide (9). S. enterica subsp. enterica (including serotypes Typhi, Paratyphi, Typhimurium, and Enteritidis) encompasses 60% of all serotypes and accounts for over 99% of human infections (9, 10). The remaining five S. enterica subspecies and S. bongori are typically environmental isolates or pathogens of cold-blooded animals and are rarely implicated in human disease (9). Gastrointestinal illness, the most common presentation of nontyphoidal Salmonella infection, is estimated to affect nearly 100 million people globally on an annual basis (11). This equates to approximately 3% of all cases of diarrheal illness. The regional incidence of infection varies widely from as low as 250/100,000 in Central and North America to 690/100,000 in Europe and nearly 4,000/100,000 in East and Southeast Asia. In the United States, Salmonella spp. are second only to norovirus as a cause of foodborne illness, accounting for >1.35 million infections and >26,000 hospitalizations annually. S. Enteritidis, S. Typhimurium, and S. Newport are the three serotypes most commonly associated with gastroenteritis and account for approximately 50% of reported infections (12). The mortality rate associated with nontyphoidal Salmonella infection is approximately 0.1 to 0.5%, but it can vary based on host factors such as nutrition, immunocompromised status, and access to health care (11, 13). Infection with “typhoidal” Salmonella, namely, S. Typhi or S. Paratyphi, causes a systemic illness commonly known as enteric fever, which is endemic in Asia, India, and South Africa. The incidence of enteric fever is highest in Pakistan and India, reaching 200 to 450 cases per 100,000 population, and carries a mortality rate of 1 to 7% (14). The incidence of enteric fever in North America and Europe is low, with 70 to 80% of cases occurring in travelers returning from regions of endemicity (13, 15).

NontyphoidalSalmonella (NTS) is a common inhabitant of the gastrointestinal tract of wild and domestic poultry, which serves as an important reservoir for infection, but is also frequently isolated from warm-blooded mammals and reptiles. Chronic asymptomatic carriage of NTS by humans following infection is rare, occurring in approximately 1:1,000 cases, but may also serve as a source of infection (1, 14). Between 90 and 95% of all Salmonella infections are foodborne (11, 13); large outbreaks have also been linked to close contact with animals, including “backyard poultry” and pet turtles (16). Foods most commonly implicated in transmission of Salmonella are undercooked poultry and eggs; however, fresh produce and processed foods such as chocolate and peanut butter have also been implicated in recent large outbreaks in the United States and Europe (14, 16). In addition, foods can be cross-contaminated if prepared using instruments or surfaces, such as cutting boards, that were previously contaminated. Between 40 and 100% of a Salmonella inoculum can be recovered from wooden or plastic cutting boards within 30 min of contamination, and Salmonella spp. can persist for >24 h on dry surfaces. All Salmonella serotypes are acid labile and susceptible to the low pH of the stomach; therefore, the infective dose via ingestion is relatively high, ranging from 105 to 1010 viable organisms (17). The variance in infective dose may be serotype specific and is likely impacted by the food vehicle, with high-fat foods and milk conferring a lower infective dose due to neutralization of stomach pH.

S. Typhi and S. Paratyphi are strict human pathogens and have no animal or environmental reservoirs. They may be more susceptible to environmental stresses than other serotypes and remain viable for only 6 h on inanimate surfaces (18). Up to 5% of individuals infected with S. Typhi or S. Paratyphi become chronic asymptomatic carriers, shedding the bacterium for up to 10 years (19). Carriage is frequently restricted to the gallbladder; 90% of carriers have gallstones, which serve as a surface for biofilm formation. This likely contributes to bacterial persistence and resistance to antimicrobial treatment aimed at decolonization (19).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: In healthy adults, NTS infection is a self-limited disease characterized by nonbloody diarrhea, sometimes accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and fever. Disease is typically restricted to the gastrointestinal tract and only infrequently disseminates to extraintestinal sites. Symptoms arise following a short incubation period of 6 to 72 h after ingestion of the bacterium and last 3 to 10 days (1, 14). Rarely, asymptomatic colonization of the gallbladder can lead to chronic inflammation and may increase the risk for cholecystitis and cholelithiasis, which are risk factors leading to adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder (18, 19). Reduced stomach acidity in infants and individuals taking antacids or proton pump inhibitors increases susceptibility to infection (1). Individuals with HIV infection, asplenia, diabetes, and iatrogenic immunosuppression and the elderly have a 20-times-higher risk for infection than the general public (1, 14, 20). Bloodstream infection (BSI) complicates <5% of all NTS gastrointestinal infections. Patients with solid tumors, diabetes, AIDS, or hematologic malignancies account for >60% of BSIs due to NTS; however, young children and the elderly are also at elevated risk (21). In adults >50 years of age, approximately 25 to 35% of BSIs due to NTS result in endocarditis (1). Univariate analysis demonstrates that an age of >65 and immunosuppression are statistically associated with increased mortality (29 to 35% mortality; odds ratio [OR], 5.8 to 6.8) following NTS bacteremia (21). Importantly, <10% of patients with NTS bacteremia have a history of gastroenteritis (22). Therefore, lack of diarrhea should not rule out suspicion for Salmonella bacteremia, especially in an immunocompromised patient population. Immunocompromised populations are also at risk for extraintestinal infections, such as meningitis, osteomyelitis, pneumonia, and septic arthritis (14). In a pediatric population, those with an immunosuppressive condition had a 25 to 30% incidence of extraintestinal infection secondary to BSI, compared to <4% incidence in immunocompetent children (1). In adult immunocompromised patients, 15 to 20% develop metastatic focal infections, with an associated 16% mortality (1).

Typhoid fever and paratyphoid fever are systemic infections caused byS. Typhi and S. Paratyphi A, B, and C, respectively. The associated systemic infections are clinically indistinguishable and are all referred to as enteric fever. Unlike NTS disease, enteric fever has an indolent onset and is characterized by low-level bacteremia (~1 CFU/ml) and seeding of extraintestinal sites, including the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and gallbladder (23). The incubation period after ingestion of the bacterium is typically 7 to 14 days, and initial symptoms are nonspecific, including low-grade fever, headache, cough, myalgia, and general malaise (23). Nausea and abdominal discomfort may be present, but diarrhea is uncommon in immunocompetent individuals. If left untreated, symptoms progress to include high-grade fever with development of a maculopapular rash on the abdomen, arms, and legs in up to 30% of cases (23). Patients with prolonged untreated infection (>2 weeks) are at risk for more severe complications, including gastrointestinal hemorrhage or perforation, hepatitis, myocarditis, delirium, meningitis, pneumonia, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and septic shock. The hospitalization rate for patients with enteric fever is >60% in the United States; however, in developing countries where enteric fever is endemic, 60 to 90% of infections are unreported or managed with empiric antibiotic treatment in outpatient settings (15, 23). When the disease is left untreated, the overall case fatality rate is <1% but can reach 30 to 50% in patients hospitalized with severe disease who do not receive appropriate antibiotic therapy (23). Relapse with a milder clinical course is observed in 5 to 10% of patients within a month of symptom resolution.

The pathogenesis ofSalmonella is driven by the ability to actively invade and replicate within gastric epithelial cells and evade clearance by phagocytes. Chromosomally encoded effectors (e.g., those encoded by sipA, sipC, sopE, and sptP) act in concert to modulate the host cell actin cytoskeleton and induce phagocytosis of the bacterium through a process known as membrane ruffling (24). This is a rapid process that occurs within 10 to 15 min of bacterial contact with epithelial cells and does not cause cellular lesions or death (24, 25). Additional effectors stimulate fluid loss and expression of inflammatory cytokines, resulting in an influx of macrophages and neutrophils and watery diarrhea.

S. Typhi and S. Paratyphi can cause systemic infection (i.e., enteric fever). An understanding of the genetic mechanisms underlying this pathogenesis is hampered by the lack of an animal model; therefore, current knowledge is based primarily on experiments using S. Typhimurium, which causes a typhoid fever-like illness in mice. Based on comparative genomic studies, S. Typhi encodes a unique surface-expressed protein known as Vi antigen (viaB) and a multimeric “typhoid” cytotoxin that are absent from NTS (25). Expression of Vi antigen prevents complement-mediated killing, while cytotoxins encoded by pltA, cdtB, and pltC target host DNA to suppress the inflammatory response (25, 26). Combined, this immune suppression and cytotoxic activity may contribute to the indolent course, dissemination, persistence, and relapse observed in patients with enteric fever.

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS

sect1.title: Optimal Specimen
sect1.para: Detailed methods for the collection, transport, and storage of enteric pathogens are described inchapter 19. Specifically regarding isolation of Salmonella for gastroenteritis, fresh stool specimens are the preferred sample and should be cultured within 2 h of collection or transferred into a nonnutritive buffered transport medium (see “Transport and Storage” for details regarding transport media) and stored at 4°C to preserve the viability of bacteria in the specimen (27). Collection of stool does not strictly require the use of sterile containers, but the specimen should not be contaminated with toilet water or urine, as these sources could introduce contamination into the specimen. For children in diapers, commercial collection devices are available, but a common collection method is to line diapers with plastic wrap or to use nonabsorbent diapers. The use of a plastic barrier will prevent the stool specimen from soaking into the diaper. An alternative is to test rectal swabs; however, swabs are less sensitive than stool for culture, with a reported 64% sensitivity (28). Although fecal specimens should be prioritized when performing culture, Salmonella molecular testing demonstrates similar sensitivities with stool and rectal swabs (29–31). If such specimens are accepted, the laboratory should verify visible soiling of swabs as a measure of quality specimen sampling.

Aside from sample type and transport vessel, the timing of specimen collection and number of specimens collected can affect the sensitivity of testing. Collection of a single stool specimen during the acute phase of infection recovers the etiological agent of community-acquired diarrhea in 94 to 98% of cases (32–34). When culture is negative, additional fecal specimens can be tested, but they should be collected on separate days (27). Current guidelines state that up to three stools may be required to completely rule out bacterial infections using culture (32, 34). Stool specimens for Salmonella testing should not be routinely submitted from inpatients hospitalized for >3 days, as studies with both culture and molecular testing have shown that almost no Salmonella spp. are recovered/identified from these patients (35, 36). For children, this may be extended to 4 days. In applying these rules to inpatients, consideration should be given to the potential for visitors to bring in food prepared outside the health care environment. The effects of testing multiple stools with molecular assays have not yet been evaluated. As molecular assays can be more sensitive than culture, the utility of testing additional specimens from the same patient will likely be limited and not cost effective. Molecular assays should also not be used for test of cure (37).

Culturing of blood, bone marrow, duodenal contents, and/or urine can be carried out when typhoid fever is suspected based on travel history and symptoms. When blood is collected for culture, a standard 40 to 60 ml of blood distributed across two or three sets is recommended (see reference4 for further information); due to the low bacterial burden in S. Typhi infections, it is especially important to ensure that an adequate volume of blood is submitted when S. Typhi is suspected (23). Blood cultures are positive in 40 to 70% of cases, with highest rates observed in the first week of illness (38, 39). Bone marrow and duodenal cultures of samples from adults demonstrate the highest sensitivity for culture of S. Typhi, but these specimens are rarely submitted due to their invasive collection requirements. These cultures reach 80 to 90% positivity in confirmed typhoid cases, regardless of antibiotic treatment (38, 39). In pediatric patients, duodenal contents offer little value in children 2 to 6 years old (40). Stool cultures should not be relied upon for diagnosis, as only 30% of patients with typhoid fever have organisms isolated from stool (23). The impact of molecular stool testing as an aid in the diagnosis of typhoid fever has not been evaluated.

sect1.title: Transport and Storage
sect1.para: Correct transport of fecal specimens is essential for obtaining quality results for stool culture. To minimize loss of bacterial viability, testing should be performed within the first 2 h of collection for raw stool. If testing will be delayed longer than this, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that raw stool cultures be stored frozen at less than −15°C and rectal swabs be frozen at −70°C until testing is possible; however, it is more practical to inoculate stools into a transport medium to stabilize microbial populations, allowing storage for up to 2 to 3 days at room temperature prior to testing. Regarding molecular testing, transport and storage of stool specimens follow guidelines like those for bacterial culture. For details on differences in transport media and their stability for stool pathogens, seechapter 39 (Escherichia and Shigella).

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: On Gram stain,Salmonella spp. are small Gram-negative rod-shaped bacteria. They are indistinguishable from other Gram-negative rods, such as other Enterobacterales. As such, direct examination of stool for presence of Salmonella with a Gram stain has no clinical utility, as Salmonella spp. cannot be distinguished from normal microbiota in the sample.

sect1.title: Specimen Enrichment for Stool Culture
sect1.para: Enrichment of stool cultures for isolation ofSalmonella spp. can increase sensitivity of culture, as these infections are caused by low numbers of bacteria. Various enrichment broths are available, including selenite broth (SB), Rappaport-Vassiliadis (RV) broth, buffered peptone water (BPW), Gram-negative (GN) broth, and MAC broth, with GN broth and SB being the most commonly used (27). These broths are selective, inhibiting growth of Gram-positive organisms as well as many Gram-negative organisms, including E. coli (41). Most broths are held at 35 ± 2°C in 5% CO2, but this can vary with the length of incubation. For example, GN broth should be incubated for only 6 to 8 h (otherwise, normal microbiota can begin to overgrow these pathogens), whereas SB is held for 18 to 24 h (41, 42). After incubation, broths need to be plated to solid media for full identification. Due to the delay in turnaround time, not all laboratories perform enrichment culture of Salmonella spp.

A comparison of the use of SB, RV broth, and BPW to direct culture was performed on 1,096 stools, and all three broths increased isolation ofSalmonella spp. (43). Direct plating yielded 102 Salmonella-positive stools, whereas SB enrichment yielded 177, RV broth yielded 197, and BPW yielded 180 positive stools. Other reports show similar increases, with one identifying an additional 26 isolates from 3,977 stools using SB enrichment (43). RV broth can inhibit growth of S. Typhi, which is why SB or GN broth is more commonly used. Molecular testing of stools is becoming more prevalent, and, similar to culture, broth enrichment can improve detection. One study evaluating 114 PCR-positive S. enterica-positive stools reanalyzed testing with and without SB incubation (12 to 16 h) (44). In that study, the authors found that without SB incubation, PCR testing of stools missed 13% of positive stools.

sect1.title: General Medium Growth Requirements
sect1.para: Isolation and identification ofSalmonella spp. from normal fecal microbiota require several selective media to increase sensitivity. As this testing is done in parallel for other stool pathogens, minimally four media should be used, including MAC agar, a selective agar for isolation of Salmonella and Shigella, a selective agar for recovery of STEC O157, and a selective agar for Campylobacter (discussed in chapter 59) (27, 32). Details specific to these stool pathogen culture methods can be found in chapter 39. Many media for Salmonella isolation overlap those for Shigella spp.; lists of common media and images of Salmonella growth are found in Table 5 and Fig. 2, respectively, of chapter 39. Standard incubation conditions are required for growth of these organisms (excluding Campylobacter spp.), including incubation at 35 ± 2°C for 18 to 48 h. When Salmonella spp. are grown from nonstool specimens, including urine, cerebrospinal fluid, and sterile fluids, blood agar and MAC agar plates should be used for isolation.

sect1.title: Plating Media for Salmonella spp.
sect1.para: Several selective media can be used for the isolation ofSalmonella from stool cultures. Common media include Hektoen enteric (HE) agar, Salmonella-Shigella (SS) agar, and xylose-lysine-deoxycholate (XLD) agar; examples of Salmonella growth on HE and XLD are shown in Fig. 2 of chapter 39. HE agar is a selective agar based on bile salts that reduce growth of Gram-positive organisms. This agar also contains increased amounts of peptone (12 g versus 3 g in MAC agar) with bromothymol blue and acid fuchsin (acid base indicators) and two H2S indicators. The increase in peptone counteracts inhibitory effects of bile salts and indicators (45). Salmonella colonies are green to blue-green and can contain a black center due to production of H2S of some strains. Proteus and Shigella spp. can appear similar in growth to Salmonella spp., so confirmation of the identification is required. SS agar is similar in composition presumptive to HE agar and allows detection of Salmonella and Shigella spp. Detection is based on fermentation of lactose (agar turns red), and Salmonella spp., a lactose nonfermenter, will appear translucent. Salmonella organisms that produce H2S can quickly be identified, as these colonies have a black spot in the center of the colony when growing on SS agar. Non-H2S-producing Salmonella spp. can appear similar to other nonfermenters, such as Shigella, and should be followed up with confirmatory testing. Proteus spp. and Gram-positive bacteria are often inhibited in SS agar as it has increased amounts of peptone relative to MAC (45). The agar also contains sodium thiosulfate and ferric citrate to allow detection of H2S produced by Salmonella spp. SS agar is highly selective and can inhibit growth of some Shigella spp. XLD agar uses both xylose and lysine for fermentation reactions. Lysine decarboxylation from Salmonella spp. will convert the agar to an alkaline detection (45). The agar also contains sodium thiosulfate and ferric ammonium citrate to detect H2S production. With these formulations, Salmonella spp. will appear red on XLD agar with a black center for H2S-producing Salmonella spp. Of note Shigella spp. will also appear red, so non-H2S-producing Salmonella need further identification.

Evaluations comparing the ability of these agars to isolateSalmonella from stools have been performed. One study tested 1,597 stool specimens using both direct and enrichment plating. Specimens were enriched with either GN broth or Selenite-F broth and then plated to XLD, HE, or SS agar. Enrichment almost doubled Salmonella isolation. Parallel plating found that XLD detected the most isolates of Salmonella spp. (83%), followed by HE agar (80%) and SS agar (74% of Salmonella spp.) (46). The authors also observed that HE and SS agar yielded twice the number of false-positive colonies compared to XLD agar.

To improve isolation, many manufacturers have developed chromogenic agar forSalmonella isolation. A variety of manufacturers make chromogenic agar for detection of Salmonella spp. from stool. Examples of currently marketed chromogenic agar are RAPID′Salmonella medium (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA), BBL CHROMagar Salmonella (BD Diagnostics, Sparks, MD), Salmonella ChromoSelect agar (Millipore, Burlington, MA), and Oxoid Salmonella chromogenic medium (Oxoid, Basingstoke, UK). As these agars use different chromogens, it is important to reference their instructions for use to determine colony color for detection and limitations. One study compared three chromogenic agars to plating on standard media (XLD, SS, and HE) (47). Testing of 1,339 stools showed that 32 Salmonella isolates were identified on at least one medium. The chromogenic agars evaluated ranged in sensitivity from 78 to 88% after 48 h of incubation. Even when compared to chromogenic agar, XLD was the most sensitive medium used in the study, at 97% (47). The authors suggest that use of enriched stools plated on BBL CHROMagar Salmonella and XLD is optimal, as 100% of Salmonella isolates were detected using this combination.

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Salmonella colonies are nondescript, resembling those of other members of the Enterobacterales, appearing as large white colonies that can be opaque or translucent. Salmonella spp. are nonhemolytic on blood agar (see Fig. 2 of chapter 39 for characteristic growth), except for S. Abortusequi and S. Gallinarum, which can be weakly hemolytic (48). Salmonella isolates are colorless on MAC agar, and all but S. Paratyphi are positive for H2S production. Salmonella isolates are oxidase negative and catalase positive (49). On triple sugar iron agar, Salmonella is K/A with or without gas production, depending on the strain (Fig. 1). Species and subspecies can be identified by biochemicals found in Tables 1 and 2. Important biochemical properties to differentiate Salmonella serotypes are gas production in triple sugar iron (S. Typhi is negative) and ornithine decarboxylase, which is negative for S. Typhi and positive for S. Paratyphi A (49); however, the genus is diverse, and atypical strains can occur, making identification difficult. Phenotypic identification is commonly combined with serotyping for confirmation.

Rapid phenotypic assays such as VITEK 2, MicroScan, and BD Phoenix can be used for identification, but they have been found to have some issues, likely due to strain diversity. Studies by O’Hara (52) and by O’Hara and Miller (50, 51) evaluated various enteric isolates for overall performance of detecting common stool pathogens. In the O’Hara study (50), testing with VITEK 2 found that four lactose-positive Salmonella strains were reported as E. coli with a “very good” confidence value (50). Using MicroScan, there were five misidentifications, with four being reported with >90% probability as either E. coli, Shigella, or Leminorella spp. (51). A total of seven misidentifications were observed with Phoenix, which also included an additional 18 fresh isolates (non-CDC library). Six were reported as E. coli and one as Shigella sonnei (52). Overall, the sensitivity of these systems is high, but due to variability of biochemical reactions when isolates are recovered from stool, follow-up biochemical testing should be performed to confirm identification. Furthermore, isolates of Salmonella spp. should be sent to a public health facility for typing.

Two matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time-of-flight mass spectrometry systems (MALDI-TOF MS), the VITEK MS (BioMérieux, Durham, NC) and MALDI Biotyper (Bruker Daltonics Inc., Billerica, MA), have become standard practice for many laboratories for identification of isolates. Both have FDA-cleared and research-use-only (RUO) libraries that includeSalmonella. Overall, Salmonella spp. are accurately identified to the genus level (53, 54). The current Bruker Biotyper libraries cannot readily differentiate serotypes, so it is recommended that follow-up serotyping be performed when required for patient care. Possible future updates to libraries may differentiate serotypes by measuring specific m/z peaks; however, these applications are still in the research phase (55, 56). The VITEK MS database does allow differentiation of Salmonella spp., and in one study, it correctly identified three of five typhoidal serovars tested, although the manufacturer recommends additional serovar testing for confirmation (57). Both instruments require RUO libraries for identification of S. bongori.

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Amplification Testing of Stool
sect1.para: Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods have been applied to the identification ofSalmonella spp., and are often paired to detect multiple other bacterial, viral, and protozoan agents associated with acute gastroenteritis. Several FDA-cleared multiplexed molecular panels have been developed that can detect 3 to 22 individual targets (see Table 7 in chapter 39). Narrow or focused panels often identify Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter spp. and genes encoding Shiga toxins (stx1 and stx2), while broad panels include multiple additional bacterial, viral, and protozoan pathogens. These panels range from high-complexity tests requiring off-line extraction and manual setup of individual real-time PCRs to moderate-complexity sample-to-result platforms capable of generating a result in approximately 1 h.

Results from clinical trial and research studies have demonstrated excellent performance for the detection ofSalmonella spp., with reported sensitivities ranging from 82.7 to 100% in preserved stool specimens (58–61). Furthermore, sensitivity appears to be higher than conventional culture and broth-enriched enzyme immunoassay (EIA) methods. In one study, there were an additional 19 positives compared to culture, which was a 66% increase in positive detections (62). The increased rate of detection is directly related to a 1- to 2-log10 difference in limit of detection between culture and NAAT. Using an FDA-cleared NAAT, Anderson et al. (62) reported 100% sensitivity for Salmonella spp., at a concentration of 105 CFU/ml and 69% sensitivity at 104 CFU/ml, followed by 44% at 103 CFU/ml in stool matrix. This contrasts with culture methods, which demonstrated 100% sensitivity at 106 CFU/ml, diminished upon dilution to 81, 31, and 0% per log CFU/ml (62).

NAAT assays also improve the turnaround forSalmonella detection. Depending on the assay and level of automation in extraction and testing, results are available in 8 h for manually batched assays or 1 h for more sample-to-answer assays. The decreased time to result has the potential to positively impact patient management and infection control efforts. Empirical antibiotic treatment is not recommended in uncomplicated cases of gastroenteritis; however, antibiotics are frequently prescribed and may be appropriate for children <3 months of age, persons with severe diarrhea, or persons with systemic disease (63). In these cases, a rapid, highly sensitive and specific assay could result in reducing empiric antibiotic treatment or at a minimum allow discontinuation of antibiotics that are not needed for the pathogen detected.

While molecular assays are highly sensitive and significantly faster than conventional methods, laboratories need to consider the high cost of the test, as well as the associated cost to the patient or insurer and the clinical utility of rapid results. Laboratories may want to limit testing to complicated cases or inpatient testing, as there is limited information on the clinical impact of a rapid molecular result for outpatients with uncomplicated gastroenteritis. For complicated cases or severely ill patients, a molecular assay may be useful; however, at the time of writing, there are no large studies examining the impact of molecular panels on antibiotic stewardship, patient outcome, or overall cost of care. Current guidelines for diagnosis of infectious diarrhea recommend a selective and targeted approach, including testing for onlySalmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, and Yersinia spp., Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) including serotype O157, and Clostridioides difficile based on exposure, risk factors, and clinical symptoms (63). Several narrow molecular panels are available that cover these pathogens and are listed in Table 7 of chapter 39 (64). Current guidelines also suggest that diagnostic testing is not routinely recommended for mild cases of acute gastroenteritis lasting <7 days unless the patient is at risk for severe disease (63, 65). For patients with persistent diarrhea (>7 days), fever, leukocytosis, and history of travel; infants; and patients who are immunocompromised, a broader pathogen differential, including parasites and uncommon bacterial pathogens, may be considered (63, 65). For these patients, use of broad-panel testing may be warranted. NAATs have also been found to be positive well after treatment and resolution of symptoms. Because NAATs are unable to differentiate between viable and nonviable organisms, they are not recommended for use as a test of cure (63). When a test of cure is required for selected populations (food handlers, health care workers, and children returning to child care), a negative stool culture can be considered to support low risk of transmissibility (63).

A weakness of exclusive reliance on NAAT for detection of gastrointestinal pathogens is the lack of recovery of an isolate. These assays report only to genus level, potentially leading to negative impacts on public health and epidemiology efforts. Recovery of a bacterial isolate is critical to outbreak investigation and identification of emerging bacterial serotypes associated with gastroenteritis. Further, phenotypic antimicrobial susceptibility testing requires an isolate. Therefore, the ability to conduct routine bacterial culture on stool specimens should be maintained. However, if NAAT is employed as a first-line diagnostic test, culture may be selectively utilized for only those specimens that test positive or when antimicrobial susceptibility results are necessary for clinical care. Maintenance of routine culture methods is also important to support public health and surveillance goals (63).

sect1.title: NAAT and Antigen Detection from Nonstool Specimens
sect1.para: The role ofSalmonella infections in bloodstream infections and endocarditis has led to some assay developers adding primers and probes specific for the detection of Salmonella to their blood culture panels. Prevalence is low, and studies in Finland, Australia, Denmark, and Canada have found incidence rates of 1.02 per 100,000 population (66). Prevalence can be higher in other countries, with rates as high as 100 per 100,000 population in Africa (67). To date, only two panels have a Salmonella target that is FDA cleared: BioFire BCID2 (bioMerieux, Marcy l’Etoile, FR) and the GenMark ePlex BCID-GN panel (GenMark, Carlsbad, CA). In addition, due to the low prevalence, prospective studies evaluating these assays have a limited number of Salmonella cases. Clinical trial data from the BioFire BCID2 found 100% sensitivity and specificity for Salmonella spp., which was replicated in a separate study; however these data are limited, as only one prospective Salmonella specimen was tested during the evaluation (68). The clinical performance reported in the package insert found 100% positive percent agreement (PPA) for detection of Salmonella spp., which included 5 prospective specimens, 16 frozen archived specimens, and 37 seeded samples (68). Similar results were found for the GenMark ePlex BCID-GN panel, as the FDA submission found a PPA of 96% (discordant analysis agreed with ePlex result), and another study found 100% agreement, but with the limitation of a single positive specimen tested in the prospective trial (69, 70). Further studies are needed to fully evaluate these assays at a clinical level, but molecular identification is likely sensitive and can be linked to detection of antimicrobial resistance genes, which coming from a nonsterile source requires follow-up phenotypic antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST) to link resistance to the pathogen. However, these panels report only the genus, so further characterization of subcultured isolates is needed.

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Strain typing strategies forEnterobacterales, which were previously based primarily on antigenic methods, have undergone recent and dramatic evolution with the advent of next-generation sequencing (NGS)-based approaches. The widespread adoption of NGS techniques has allowed detailed lineage studies of epidemiologically significant strains and fine-scale tracking of transmission chains in hospital, community, and foodborne outbreaks. Furthermore, development of public central tracking systems such as the FDA’s GenomeTrakr Network, in which sequenced outbreak genomes are deposited and indexed, has allowed geographic mapping of outbreak lineages in real time. In this section, we begin with traditional classification schemes based on antigenic typing, pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE), and multilocus sequence typing (MLST) and then cover newer molecular and NGS-based approaches, including ribosomal MLST (rMLST), whole-genome and core-genome MLST (wgMLST and cgMLST), and whole-genome single-nucleotide variant (SNV)-based strain tracking.

sect1.title: Antigenic Typing of Salmonella spp.
sect1.para: Compared with other genera ofEnterobacterales, Salmonella spp. display remarkable antigenic diversity. Consequently, specific methods have been developed for antigenic typing of this genus, and these are reviewed below. For a more general overview of antigenic typing methods for Enterobacterales, see chapter 39. Salmonella spp. have classically been typed based on O, H, and Vi antigens, and serotypes are classified by the White-Kauffmann-Le Minor (WKL) scheme (71–73). This scheme defines more than 2,500 serotypes, with the majority causing disease in humans belonging to S. enterica subspecies enterica (74). Typing usually begins with O antigen antisera, as O serogroup determination is sufficient to confirm isolates as belonging to the genus Salmonella. Depending on the exact approach, O antigen groups are tested successively in pools, followed by testing with individual antisera. O antigen groups were originally designated by letters, and subsequently, each O antigen has been individually numbered. Although numbers are used in the antigenic formulae of the WKL scheme, O antigen groups are still referred to by letters by many typing laboratories.

Following O antigen determination, the H group is typed.Salmonella spp. are unusual among Enterobacterales in that many Salmonella serotypes encode two flagellar proteins, designated H1 and H2, referred to as phase 1 and phase 2 antigens, respectively (75, 76), and strains that are capable of switching between the expression of two flagellar proteins are referred to as diphasic. Strains expressing only one H antigen are referred to as monophasic, with S. Typhi and S. Enteritidis constituting important examples. Rare nonmotile strains may not express detectable H antigen (74). Different parts of flagellin proteins may be recognized separately by different antibodies in antisera used for typing, thus defining multiple H1 or H2 antigenic determinants present simultaneously for a single flagellin protein. Consequently, multiple antigenic assignments may be made to each of the H antigen group phases; these are distinguished by numbers in antigenic formulae. It is now known that in most Salmonella isolates, phase 1 H antigens are encoded by the fliC gene and phase 2 H antigens by the fljB gene (76, 77). A third antigen used for typing of Salmonella spp. is the Vi antigen. The Vi antigen in Salmonella spp. is controlled by the viaA and viaB loci, found predominantly in typhoidal strains, although Vi is also expressed in some Citrobacter isolates (78), so Vi antigen alone cannot be used for primary classification without excluding Citrobacter spp. by independent methods.

Salmonella serotypes are formally named within the WKL scheme as follows: subspecies [space] O antigen(s), Vi antigen if present: phase 1 H antigen(s): phase 2 H antigens(s) if present. Serotypes belonging to subspecies I (S. enterica subsp. enterica) are also often given a name, with more than 1,500 named serotypes (71). By convention, these serotype names are capitalized and not italicized. Furthermore, many authors choose to omit the designation “subsp. enterica” when referring to the serotype by name, as other subspecies do not receive names and are referred to only with antigenic formulae. Because Salmonella strains actively exchange genetic material, novel antigenic combinations arise that are not easily classified within the WKL scheme (79); molecular methods for dealing with these strains are discussed below. Two of the most common pathogenic serotypes of S. enterica subsp. enterica are the monophasic S. Enteritidis (serotype I 9,12:g,m:−) and the diphasic S. Typhimurium (serotype I 4,[5],12:i:1,2) (71). Serotypes, in turn, are organized into larger serogroups. Table 3 compares serogroups and common serotypes.

sect1.title: Traditional Molecular Methods
sect1.para: The antigenic approaches described above depend on the production and maintenance of >250 antigen-specific antisera, limiting testing to a small number of public health and reference labs. For this reason, a variety of molecular methods that can be performed on instruments widely available to clinical labs without the need for specialized reagents have begun to play an increasingly important role inSalmonella classification. For a general discussion of these methods, including PFGE and MLST approaches, see chapter 12. For Salmonella spp., studies of PFGE have demonstrated 75 to 99% concordance with classical serotyping following categorization of pulsotypes, depending on the diversity of the isolate set and chosen restriction enzyme (74). MLST has many advantages over PFGE testing, given the reliability of PCR, on which it is based, and the widespread familiarity with PCR instruments. MLST has been extensively compared with classical serotype classifications for Salmonella spp. and has been found to have certain advantages, although not all serotypes are distinguishable as unique sequence types in standard MLST schemes. Comparative studies performed with MLST schemes based on three, four, and seven genes demonstrate concordances with classical serotyping of 88 to 100%, depending on the scheme and isolates (74, 80).

sect1.title: NGS-Based Typing
sect1.para: The increasing availability of NGS instruments and large reference genome databases has made possible new approaches to bacterial strain typing. In this section, we focus on the details of selected genomic approaches for predictingSalmonella serotypes and epidemiologic investigations. For a general discussion of the application of NGS methods for bacterial typing and epidemiology, see chapter 12.

The development of genomic approaches forSalmonella serotype prediction has benefited substantially from the efforts of the CDC’s PulseNet National Laboratory Network and the FDA’s GenomeTrakr, which have correlated classical serotypes, PFGE pulsotypes, and whole-genome sequencing (WGS) genotypes for a large number of isolates. Uploaded genomes from these programs may be found in the NCBI Pathogen Detection Database (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pathogens/), and genomic data from more than 400,000 Salmonella isolates are available. A number of stand-alone bioinformatics pipelines that take either assembled genome contigs or raw reads for input and predict a serotype have been developed, and here, we focus on two commonly used programs: Salmonella In Silico Typing Resource (SISTR) (81) and SeqSero (82). SISTR is an open-source program available for local installation or as a web-based tool (https://github.com/phac-nml/sistr_cmd) that incorporates the Salmonella genoserotyping array method (83) for serotype assignment along with rMLST and cgMLST analysis. SISTR takes as input a minimally processed draft genome and analyzes variations in the rfb gene cluster’s O-antigen flippase (wzx) and polymerase (wzy) genes and H-antigen flagellin genes, fliC and fljB, to generate a serotype prediction. Two published validations of SISTR demonstrated 94.6% and 94.8% concordance with traditional serotyping (81, 84). SeqSero is another open-source program available for local installation (https://github.com/denglab/SeqSero) or as a web-based tool (www.denglab.info/SeqSero). Similar to SISTR, SeqSero performs serotyping based on the rfb gene cluster and fliC and fliB genes and can identify >2,300 serotypes from both raw sequencing reads and draft assemblies. Two studies demonstrated concordance with traditional serotypes that ranged from 88.2 to 98.7% (82, 84). It should be noted that with both genomic approaches, discrepancies occur when genes are carried by an isolate in the genome but not expressed antigenically. Some have thus suggested reframing serotyping in terms of genome composition (84).

For epidemiologic tracking ofSalmonella spp. in outbreaks, cgMLST, wgMLST, and whole-genome SNV-based approaches have been used successfully (85–87). A range of similarity criteria have been used for cluster definition in published outbreak investigations, and it is important to note that any applied threshold needs to be evaluated in the context of the approach (whole genome or core genome; allele based or variant based) and the epidemiological structure of the outbreak. For whole-genome SNV-based approaches, similarity levels of 10 to 20 or fewer SNVs with clear monophyletic population structure have been viewed as generally indicative of clonal relatedness and single-source origin (88, 89).

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Antimicrobial therapy is not recommended for uncomplicated cases ofSalmonella gastroenteritis, and therefore, routine susceptibility testing of fecal isolates is not warranted for treatment purposes (65). However, determination of antimicrobial susceptibility is valuable for surveillance purposes to monitor the development and spread of antimicrobial resistance among Salmonella isolates. In addition, treatment with an active antimicrobial agent is crucial for patients with invasive nontyphoidal Salmonella and typhoidal infections, and susceptibilities of these isolates should be reported as soon as possible (65). Wild-type isolates of Salmonella spp. are susceptible to most antimicrobial agents, with the notable exceptions of first- and second-generation cephalosporins, cephamycin, and aminoglycosides, which may appear active in vitro but are ineffective clinically (90). Traditionally, ampicillin, chloramphenicol, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole were first-line therapy for serious Salmonella infections (91). Resistance to these agents first evolved in S. Typhi in the late 1980s, emerging in Pakistan, India, and Southeast Asia. At this time, fluoroquinolones were the drug of choice, but resistance quickly emerged in the 1990s, leading to widespread use of expanded-spectrum cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone and cefixime), macrolides (e.g., azithromycin), or carbapenems for treatment of typhoid fever (91). The recent emergence of an extensively drug-resistant (XDR) S. Typhi H58 haplotype, resistant to the first-line agents chloramphenicol, ampicillin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole as well as second-line fluoroquinolones and expanded-spectrum cephalosporins, is of significant concern (92). More than 10,365 infections with XDR S. Typhi were reported as of 2019 in Pakistan (93), and numerous cases have been reported in Iraq (94). In 2021, the CDC issued an alert regarding U.S.-acquired infections caused by this XDR strain of S. Typhi (95).

A recent meta-analysis of the literature demonstrated that among global reports in 2015 to 2018, 37% ofS. Typhi isolates were resistant to chloramphenicol, 42% to ampicillin, and 39% to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (96). In total, roughly one-third (33% of 5,621 tested) of isolates were multidrug resistant (MDR). Resistance to second-line agents was also common: 36% of isolates were not susceptible to ciprofloxacin, 6% were resistant to expanded-spectrum cephalosporins, and 7% were resistant to azithromycin. The rate of meropenem resistance was 3%, driven by unconfirmed reports of meropenem-resistant S. Typhi in Pakistan and Indonesia (96). Phylogenetic analysis has demonstrated that the global S. Typhi population is highly clonal, which has driven this global emergence of MDR strains. In particular, the MDR S. Typhi H58 lineage, which emerged in the early 1990s and harbors an IncHI1 MDR plasmid and chromosomal mutations conferring fluoroquinolone resistance, is rapidly replacing non-H58 S. Typhi globally (97).

Over the past 2 decades, increasing levels of resistance to first-line antimicrobial agents among nontyphoidalSalmonella isolates have also been described, particularly among the serotypes S. Enteritidis, S. Typhimurium, S. Newport, I 4,[5],12:i:−, and S. Heidelberg (98). Overall, MDR nontyphoidal Salmonella isolates in the United States remain rare. The most recent data reported by the CDC’s National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System documented that 1% of 2,967 nontyphoidal Salmonella isolates displayed an MDR phenotype in 2018.

Resistance to the fluoroquinolones is typically mediated by alterations in the quinolone resistance-determining regions (QRDR) of the drug’s target enzymes, DNA gyrase (gyrA and gyrB) and topoisomerase IV (parE or parC). The effect of these mutations is cumulative, leading to frank resistance (MIC ≥ 4.0 μg/ml) to fluoroquinolones and to nalidixic acid (MIC ≥ 32 μg/ml) (99). Plasmid-mediated quinolone resistance (PMQR) emerged in the 2000s (100), including the qnr family, antibiotic efflux pump genes (qepA and oqxAB), and fluoroquinolone modification enzymes [acc(6)Ib-cr]. PMQR mechanisms lead to decreased susceptibility to ciprofloxacin (MIC ≥ 0.12 μg/ml) but may not lead to resistance to nalidixic acid. Nonetheless, decreased susceptibility to ciprofloxacin has been shown to lead to treatment failure in patients with Salmonella infections (15), leading both the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) and European Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (EUCAST) to lower the Salmonella fluoroquinolone breakpoints to ≤0.06 μg/ml (ciprofloxacin) and ≤0.12 μg/ml (levofloxacin). Among nontyphoidal isolates, qnr genes are the most common PMQR determinant (101, 102). qnr genes encode a pentapeptide repeat protein that protects type II topoisomerases from the quinolones (103). Current U.S. studies demonstrate increasing levels of ciprofloxacin-nonsusceptible isolates (MIC ≥ 0.12 μg/ml) between 1999 and 2018, with 75% of S. Typhi (n = 474) and 90.5% of S. Paratyphi A (n = 121) isolates recovered in 2018 being resistant to ciprofloxacin. The XDR S. Typhi strain H58 harbors both a qnrS PMQR gene and chromosomal mutations that confer ciprofloxacin resistance. Among nontyphoidal isolates, only 9% of 2,967 tested were not susceptible to ciprofloxacin in 2018 (104); the major contributor to ciprofloxacin-nonsusceptible rates was the serotype S. Enteritidis (98), with 20% of cases being linked to international travel.

Resistance to expanded-spectrum cephalosporins inSalmonella spp. is driven by an Ambler class A, CTX-M extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) or an Ambler class C, CMY-2 AmpC type enzyme (105). XDR S. Typhi isolates harbor an IncY plasmid carrying blaCTX-M-15 (92). Resistance to expanded-spectrum cephalosporins among nontyphoidal Salmonella isolates belonging to S. Typhimurium sequence type 313 has been reported in sub-Saharan Africa; these strains harbor an IncHI2 plasmid which encodes CTX-M-15 (106). Sporadic global reports of carbapenem resistance in Salmonella spp. include a variety of nontyphoidal serotypes that harbor the carbapenemases KPC-2, IMP-4, NDM-1, NDM-5, VIM-2, and OXA-48 (107). While carbapenem-resistant S. Typhi isolates have been reported, associated isolates have not been well characterized to date (96).

Azithromycin, an azalide antimicrobial, has been shown in multiple randomized controlled trials to be an effective oral treatment for uncomplicated typhoid fever. Wild-type isolates ofSalmonella spp. have MICs of ≤16 μg/ml, and CLSI and EUCAST have established this cutoff as the susceptible breakpoint. In contrast, isolates of S. Paratyphi A have wild-type azithromycin MICs of ≤32 μg/ml, and clinical breakpoints have not been established. Sporadic reports of S. Typhi isolates resistant to azithromycin (MIC ≥ 256 μg/ml), including the H58 haplotype, have appeared. These mutations are generally associated with the efflux pump gene acrB (108, 109).

International guidance on how to approach susceptibility testing ofSalmonella spp. is available from CLSI and EUCAST. CLSI recommendations are for testing Salmonella isolates from extraintestinal infections and S. Typhi and S. Paratyphi A, B, and C for susceptibility to ampicillin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, ciprofloxacin, and an expanded-spectrum cephalosporin. In addition, susceptibility to azithromycin may be tested and reported for extraintestinal isolates of Salmonella spp. CLSI azithromycin breakpoints are applicable only for S. Typhi (90), due to the absence of data for other S. enterica serovars. In contrast, EUCAST publishes an epidemiological cutoff value (ECV) only for azithromycin and S. Typhi of ≤16 mg/ml or a ≥12-mm zone of growth inhibition surrounding a 15-μg azithromycin disk. Salmonella spp. should not be reported as susceptible to first- and second-generation cephalosporins, cephamycins, and aminoglycosides, because these are not effective clinically.

Historically, CLSI and EUCAST endorsed nalidixic acid screening to predict the presence of QRDR mutations ingyrA and parC in Salmonella spp. and the activity of fluoroquinolones for treatment of extraintestinal Salmonella infections and typhoid fever. However, nalidixic acid screening does not detect the plasmid-borne fluoroquinolone resistance mechanisms identified with increasing frequency in isolates of S. enterica (99), including the qnrS mechanism identified in XDR S. Typhi. As an alternative, a pefloxacin disk diffusion test to predict fluoroquinolone susceptibility, as recommended by EUCAST and CLSI, can be used (110, 111). Pefloxacin disk testing is particularly useful in low-resource countries that do not have access to MIC-based test methods and that have reported technical challenges associated with reading ciprofloxacin disk diffusion tests (99). However, pefloxacin disks are not available in the United States and do not detect all fluoroquinolone resistance mechanisms, such as aac(6′)-Ib-cr. CLSI guidance indicates that the preferred test for assessing fluoroquinolone susceptibility or resistance in Salmonella spp. is ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin MIC testing, depending on the fluoroquinolone to be used therapeutically.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: The genusSalmonella is a frequent pathogen of humans, most commonly causing gastroenteritis but also causing systemic infections from bloodstream infection to meningitis when infecting a susceptible host. To complicate diagnostics, variability between biochemical reactions can mislead laboratorians, and differentiation of the numerous serovars can be complicated. Use of appropriate isolation media along with novel diagnostic techniques is improving understanding of the epidemiology of this genus and will ultimately help meet the goal of improving patient care.

When commercial systems identifySalmonella with a high level of accuracy (>90% probability), the identification is probably reliable. However, for most clinical labs, identification of Salmonella will be based on MALDI-TOF MS or phenotypic traits, which will require confirmation by O-antigen testing or molecular methods. In the interim, the isolate may be reported to the physician with a presumptive identification. Because the national surveillance systems depend on the receipt of isolates for strain typing in the United States, laboratories should follow the procedures recommended by their state health departments for reporting and submitting strains for surveillance.

The clinical laboratory acts as an early warning system, alerting the medical community to new resistance mechanisms present in clinically importantSalmonella isolates. Similar to other members of the order Enterobacterales, an increasing number of Salmonella isolates are reported to carry ESBLs and carbapenemases. The ability to recognize these isolates is critical for patient care and effective infection prevention measures.
